thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: Grand Canyon: Dimensions defy the imagination
thread.title_full: Grand Canyon: Dimensions defy the imagination

author: Dennis Wagner, USA TODAY
title: Grand Canyon: Dimensions defy the imagination
text:
With an average depth of about a mile and a length of 277 miles, the Grand Canyon is like an entire mountain range in reverse. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Grand Canyon as we know it was formed between five and six million years ago, which is still young in geological terms. Joe Klamar, AFP/Getty Images Fullscreen It's not the world's deepest canyon – the Barranca del Cobre in northern Mexico and Hell's Canyon in Idaho are deeper, among others. National Park Service Fullscreen It's arguably the most dramatic, though, thanks to the colorful layering of different types ancient rocks that have been exposed to spectacular effect. National Park Service Fullscreen A mixture of minerals gives each layer in the Canyon a different hue. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The effect is especially beautiful during sunrise and sunset. National Park Service Fullscreen With more than 4 million visitors a year, the park's services fill up quickly. Be sure and make reservations for everything. National Park Service Fullscreen The pink glow of sunrise illuminates Angel's Window, just east of Cape Royal on the North Rim. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The great outdoors takes on new meaning here. Take time to immerse yourself in the experience of a lifetime. National Park Service Fullscreen This is the most visited part of the park, due to vistas that capture the color and drama of this canyon and span miles. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Mather Point and Visitor Center Plaza on the South Rim make for a convenient spot to stop. National Park Service Fullscreen Take a hike below the rim, if only a short day hike. Pipe Creek Vista and Yavapai Point are recommended. National Park Service Fullscreen The Yavapai Observation Station makes for some stunning views. National Park Service/Michael Quinn Fullscreen One of the most prominent architectural features on the South Rim of is the Desert View Watchtower. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Built in 1932 by architect Mary Colter, the Watchtower overlooks the Eastern end of the park. National Park Service Fullscreen Today, the 70-foot tower contains a gift store and its upper floors serve as observation decks. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Lookout Studio was another creation of Mary Colter, one of the best and least altered of her creations. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen One of the most popular ways to explore the park is on the back of a mule.This 100-year-old tradition is an adventurous alternative to hiking. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Canyon's colors mix with snow during the winter months, creating new beauty. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Even just a dusting can change the look of the entire Canyon, like this view from Mather Point. National Park Service Fullscreen Of course, winter conditions can make for dangerous trails, so always pay attention to ranger alerts before hiking. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The road to Yaki Point is closed to passenger vehicles during the winter, though a shuttle can still get you there. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Colorado River cut through the rock to create the Grand Canyon as it is today. National Park Service Fullscreen Though the effects might not be visible, the river still cuts away at the rock, eroding more and more every year. National Park Service Fullscreen Two Navajo Bridges, one for pedestrians and one for vehicles, cross the Colorado, two of only six bridges to do so. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Havasu Creek's blue meets the Colorado's brown, merging together at the mouth of Havasu Creek. Erin Whittaker/National Park Service Fullscreen For a different perspective on the park, try rafting the Colorado River, where you will see the canyons from the bottom up. National Park Service Fullscreen Lees Ferry is the only place within Glen Canyon where visitors can drive to the Colorado River in over 700 miles of Canyon Country. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen There's no shortage of options to take you down the river. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Pick between whitewater or smooth water, commercial or noncommercial operators, motorized or non-motorized crafts and from 1-day to 25-day trips. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Mostly known for the Colorado River, the canyons are also fed from Deer Spring. Erin Whittaker/National Park Service Fullscreen There's more to the park than just canyons. Greenland Lake is located on the North Rim along the Cape Royal Road. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Hiking is the easiest way to get down into the canyons, and should be tried if at all possible. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Bright Angel Trail dips below the rim to immerse you in a different reality. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The entire trail is a 12-mile loop that drops sharply, and the views are so beautiful that you may not notice until you start climbing back up. www.Mountainsky.com Fullscreen The South Kaibab Trail begins with a series of tight switchbacks known as "the chimney." Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The South Kaibab Trail will take you down to Phantom Ranch, lodging on the canyon floor. National Park Service/Michael Quinn Fullscreen The trail winds as it descends, so be careful to always know how close the edge is. National Park Service Fullscreen For an entirely different view, visit the Skywalk, a glass balcony suspended 4,000 feet over the canyon floor. Hualapai Tourism, Hualapai Tribe Fullscreen Run by the Hualapai Tribe, the Skywalk charges a separate fee. Grand Canyon West is not a part of the national park. Hualapai Tourism, Hualapai Tribe Fullscreen The historic El Tovar on the South Rim, with a classic hunting-lodge feel, is the most upscale indoor lodging option. National Park Service Fullscreen It was once described as “the most expensively constructed and appointed log house in America.” Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Grand Canyon Lodge on the North Rim of Grand Canyon is often the first prominent feature that visitors see, even before viewing the canyon. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The highway ends at the lodge, whose sloped roof, huge ponderosa beams and massive limestone facade fit its 8000-foot setting. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Phantom Ranch, at the bottom of the Grand Canyon is still 2,550 feet above sea level. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen The Ranch can only be reached by mule, by foot, or by rafting the Colorado River. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Phantom Ranch is a popular stop-over point for hikers and mule riders traveling to the bottom of the Canyon via the Bright Angel or Kaibab trails. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Grand Canyon Desert View Campground is usually full by early afternoon during the busy summer months. National Park Service Fullscreen Cottonwood trees shade Bright Angel Campground and the creek is a wonderful place to cool off. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Every campsite at Cottonwood Campground has a picnic table, pack pole, and metal food storage can. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Among the largest hoofed mammals in the park, the desert bighorn sheep are relatively scarce along the rim, preferring the rocky slopes of the inner canyon. Mark Lellouch/National Park Service Fullscreen Mule deer are among the most readily seen mammals on the South Rim. National Park Service Fullscreen Cougars are the greatest leaping animal on earth and the top predator at Grand Canyon. Erin Whittaker/National Park Service Fullscreen Rock squirrels commonly bite visitors who feed or hold a finger out to them, making them the most dangerous animal in the park. Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Elk are frequently seen in and around Grand Canyon Village on the South Rim Michael Quinn/National Park Service Fullscreen Regarded as one of the rarest birds in the world, the California condor is the largest land bird in North America with a wingspan up to 9 1/2 feet. Chad Olson/National Park Service Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The view from Pima Point on the south rim of the Grand Canyon at the Grand Canyon National Park on Tuesday, May 13, 2014. (Photo: David Wallace, The Arizona Republic)
171 CONNECT 24 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE In a bunkhouse at Phantom Ranch, on the floor of the Grand Canyon, Laura Beutelman answers a phone call. She's just completed another day of trail work, and someone is asking how best to appreciate one of the world's seven natural wonders.
"If you can find your own little spot — just sitting and watching everything happen around you, listening to river, the birds, the wind — almost all of your cares go away," says Beutelman, 25, a volunteer with the Arizona Conservation Corps. "It's part of the magic of this place."
In fact, the experience at Grand Canyon National Park is all about perspectives. As first-time visitors approach the canyon rim, they are captured by the grandeur, plus a sense that the void is sucking them over the edge.
Those who venture beneath the overlooks discover a whole new sensation: immersion into a geological time warp that affects each individual differently. Some feel a spiritual envelopment. Some, listening to breezes swoosh against 2-billion-year-old rock layers, encounter new perspectives on life.
The dimensions are stunning: 277 zigzagging miles carved by the Colorado River, more than a mile deep and up to 18 miles wide. Because of twists and side canyons, a full-circuit around the perimeter would cover more than 2,600 miles — greater than the air distance from New York to LA.
People take in sunset from Pima Point on the south rim of the Grand Canyon at the Grand Canyon National Park on Tuesday, May 13, 2014. (Photo: David Wallace, The Arizona Republic)
Scott Thybony, a freelance author who has guided raft trips and treks through the canyon for four decades, once said the spectacle remains unique even after hundreds of visits: "Every time I go, it's different, it's new. The inhuman scale of it is hard to get a handle on. You need to hike into it, take a mule train down the trail, float the river, fly over it."
Each year, more than 4.5 million people from all over the world accept that invitation. They take pictures of multicolored cliffs sculpted by water and wind over the eons. They leave with an indelible life experience that includes that stomach-flipping sensation on the brink.
Frequent visitors talk about the solitude and space, a transformative timelessness.
Bryan Struble, a National Park trail maintenance worker and photographer, recommends a hike at least partway into the chasm. "There's always a different experience," he says. "When you're touching the resource with your hands, smelling it, wind in your face, and a thunderstorm comes through. … Find your serenity."
Grand Canyon National Park covers 1,900 square miles, an area larger than Rhode Island. The more accessible South Rim (80 miles from Flagstaff, Ariz., and 228 miles from Phoenix) is open year-round and attracts 90% of visitors. The remote North Rim (266 miles from Las Vegas) closes in the winter.
The place is safe enough that children, seniors and people with disabilities can enjoy the splendor, yet dangerous enough that, each year, careless visitors die from falls, heat stroke and dehydration.
For first-timers, the big question is how to get the best out of this overwhelming attraction. You can hike trails atop the rim, backpack into the abyss for a camping experience, join a multiday rafting adventure on the Colorado, ride a mule to rustic cabins or get the bird's-eye view from a helicopter.
The mesmerizing panorama cannot be captured in postcards or conjured in poetry. Yet casual tourists find much more to do than gawk. Each day, rangers offer free interpretive classes and treks.
National Park entry fees will increase on June 1 to $30 from $25 for a seven-day vehicle permit, and to $15 from $12 for those arriving by train, raft or on foot. (Other fees, such as backpacking permits, also have increased.) Tours and overnight accommodations, including Grand Canyon lodges and campgrounds, fill up in peak seasons and on weekends.
Wagner also reports for The Arizona Republic of Phoenix.
To learn about park sites from all 50 states, order USA TODAY’s special edition, National Treasures at onlinestore.usatoday.com. (Photo: USA Today)
About the park
Size : 1.2 million acres
Visitors : 4,756,771in 2014
Established : 1919
History : The oldest human artifacts date back nearly 12,000 years. In 1893, President Benjamin Harrison proclaimed the canyon a preserve. President Theodore Roosevelt established it as a national monument in 1908 with the words: "Do nothing to mar its grandeur, sublimity and loveliness. You cannot improve on it. But what you can do is to keep it for your children, your children's children, and all who come after you." Finally, in 1919, Congress established the national park.
When visiting : Plan ahead, stay awhile and spend some solitary time on the rim and in the abyss. Going to the Grand Canyon is not like visiting a museum. It's a vast destination best experienced with reservations and an itinerary. A great place to start is at nps.gov/grca .
Of note : One-armed explorer John Wesley Powell first navigated the Colorado River through the 277-mile canyon in wooden boats in 1869.
